column1: Watertown is a city in the U.S. state of New York and the county seat of Jefferson County. It is situated approximately 25 miles (40 km) south of the Thousand Islands
column2: and along the Black River about 5 miles (8.0 km) east of its mouth at Lake Ontario. It lies 180 miles (290 km) northwest of Albany
column3: the state capital
column4: and 328 miles (530 km) northwest of New York City.  As of the 2010 census
column7: an increase of 1.2% since 2000. The U.S. Army post Fort Drum is near the city.

column1: Named after the many falls on the Black River
column2: the city developed early in the 19th century as an industrial and manufacturing center. From years of generating industrial wealth
column3: by the early 20th century the city was said to have more millionaires per capita than any other city in the nation.

column2: Watertown is located in the central part of Jefferson County. It lies 70 miles (110 km) north of Syracuse and 31 miles (50 km) south of the Ontario border. The city is served by Watertown International Airport.

column1: The city claims to be the origin of the five and dime store and the safety pin
column2: and it is the home of Little Trees air fresheners. It manufactured the first portable steam engine. It has the longest continually operating county fair in the United States. It holds the Red and Black football franchise
column3: the oldest surviving semi-professional team in the United States.

column1: This was long part of the territory of the Iroquois Confederacy. In historic times
column2: the Onondaga and the Mohawk had occupied this area. After the American Revolutionary War
column3: they and other Iroquois nations were forced to cede most of their land to the United States under the terms of peace mediated by Great Britain. The US sold the land for development
column4: mostly to migrants from New England.

column1: The city of Watertown was settled in 1800 by pioneers from New Hampshire
column3: Henry Coffeen
column5: part of a large migration into New York from New England after the Revolutionary War. These pioneers chose the area due to the Black River
column6: which flowed west into Lake Ontario about five miles away.

column1: The pioneers' vision was for an industrial center that would draw power from the river. All the land was rough and forested. Elevation was also a problem. The western end of the town was 12 to 15 feet (3.7 to 4.6 m) higher than the eastern end
column2: with a large depression in the middle. A small stream also passed through the town.
settlers cleared the center of town to create the ambitious Public Square. During the nineteenth century
column3: several significant buildings were constructed around it. Together these have been designated as a historic district and it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP).

column1: In 1805 Watertown was designated by the legislature as the county seat of Jefferson County. It was incorporated as a village in 1816.As industry and businesses flourished
column2: successful residents built substantial retail buildings
column3: churches
column4: and private residences close to the square. The Paddock Arcade
column5: built in 1850 according to European and US models
column6: is the oldest continuously operating enclosed mall in the United States. It is also listed on the NRHP
column7: as are several significant churches and private mansions.

column1: The drop in the Black River at Watertown's location—40 feet (12 m) in the center of town
column2: and 120 feet (37 m) over 2.5 miles (4.0 km)—provided abundant water power for early industry. By the mid-19th century
column3: entrepreneurs had built paper mills and major industries
column4: including one to manufacture the first portable steam engine in 1847. In 1851
column5: the city was joined to Albany and other major cities of the state by the railroad. Other mills were added to the business base
column6: generating revenue to support the city's early public works projects
column7: such as the water system and illuminating gas works in 1853

column1: Watertown claims that Rodman native Frank W. Woolworth conceived the idea of his eponymous mercantile chain while working here in 1878. Woolworth
column2: then employed as a clerk in Moore's Store
column3: set up a successful clearance display of low-priced items. This led to his idea of a store specializing in fixed-price
column4: cut-rate merchandise. Woolworth left Watertown and opened his first store in 1879 in Utica
column6: located to the southeast in the state.

column1: Among the many manufacturing businesses was the Davis Sewing Machine Company
column2: which originated in Watertown. It was predecessor to George P. Huffman's Huffy Corporation (NYSE: HUF)
column3: now a maker of bicycles and other sporting goods. Little Trees air fresheners were developed in Watertown in 1951; the Car-Freshner Corporation headquarters and manufacturing plant is located here.

column2: Watertown was incorporated as a city. In 1920
column3: the city adopted a city manager-style of government. The Jefferson County Courthouse Complex is an example of the substantial architecture of the city
column4: and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. An early industrial city that earned great wealth for many of its citizens by the turn of the 20th century
column5: Watertown also developed an educated professional class of doctors and lawyers.

column1: A number of factors affected Watertown's progress. The economic center of the country kept moving west following development of the frontier and a shift of population into the Midwest. As Chicago boomed
column2: it attracted many of the younger people from upstate New York for its  business and professional opportunities. In the mid-20th century
column3: industrial technology shifted and jobs changed. In the restructuring of railroads and deindustrialization that took place in the mid- and late 20th century
column4: Watertown suffered economic and population declines.

column1: Today the city serves as the commercial and financial center for a large rural area. It is the closest major community to Fort Drum and the post's large population of 13
column2: 000. Since the city is located just 30 miles (48 km) from the international boundary with Canada via the Thousand Islands Bridge
column3: shopping by Canadian visitors is an important part of the local economy. It also is part of an area receiving numerous tourists and summer residents annually.
was named in the city's honor.

column1: The Black River flows westward through the city toward Lake Ontario. The Black River is a world-renowned kayaking destination. Competition-level kayaking events
column3: have been held on the river.

column2: the city's name was derived from the abundant water power available from the river. Businesses harnessed water power to create one of the early industrial centers in New York
column3: beginning with paper mills processing lumber.

column3: playgrounds

column9: and views of the city of Watertown and surrounding areas due to its high elevation. The park was designed by John C. Olmsted

column1: The Watertown market is served by four commercial television stations.  The oldest is Carthage-licensed
column3: put on the air in 1954 by the publishers of the Watertown Daily Times.  The station changed its call letters to WWNY-TV in 1965. After an unsuccessful struggle against the Federal Communications Commission and its directive for newspapers to divest themselves of television stations held within the same market
column4: the Daily Times sold WWNY-TV to United Communications Corporation of Kenosha

column2: United Communications entered into an agreement with Smith Broadcasting to operate a Fox network affiliate with low-power transmitters in Watertown and Massena. After a year of joint operation
column3: UCC took complete ownership of WNYF-CD/WWNY-CD (channel 28). Both WWNY and WNYF were sold to Atlanta-based Gray Television in 2019.

Watertown was the nexus of the Rome
column3: which was later absorbed into the New York Central Railroad  (NYC) network. Watertown sat at the junction of five different lines
column7: and Utica passed through Watertown on their way to points along the St. Lawrence River (principally
